issue.title: Hashability shouldn't depend on basic_string's allocator

blockquote.p: -1- If S is one of these string types, SV is the corresponding string view type, and s is an object of type S, then hash<S>()(s) == hash<SV>()(SV(s))

discussion.p: Despite that the hash value of a basic_string object is equivalent to the hash value of a corresponding basic_string_view object, which has no allocator, the capability to hash a basic_string depends on its allocator. All of the enabled specializations have specific allocators, which fact becomes more clear if we expand the type aliases:

If the hash value doesn't depend on the allocator type, why should we care about the allocator type? I posit that we should not, and that these ten explicit specializations should be replaced by 5 partial specializations that enable hashing basic_string specializations using these combinations of character type and traits type with any allocator type.
Set status to Tentatively Ready after seven votes in favour during reflector poll.
